### classifyLEAReg() {#acf40b35a88eb365bc4f4047a03bb1ece}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool X86InstrInfo::classifyLEAReg (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineoperand">MachineOperand</a> &amp; Src, unsigned LEAOpcode, bool AllowSP, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/register">Register</a> &amp; NewSrc, bool &amp; isKill, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineoperand">MachineOperand</a> &amp; ImplicitOp, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/livevariables">LiveVariables</a> &#42; LV, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/liveintervals">LiveIntervals</a> &#42; LIS) const</>}>
Given an operand within a <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a>, insert preceding code to put it into the right format for a particular kind of LEA instruction.

This may involve using an appropriate super-register instead (with an implicit use of the original) or creating a new virtual register and inserting COPY instructions to get the data into the right class.

Reference parameters are set to indicate how caller should add this operand to the LEA instruction.

### convertToThreeAddress() {#a57da368572a9e56d7a211cc8e12581d7}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>MachineInstr &#42; X86InstrInfo::convertToThreeAddress (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/livevariables">LiveVariables</a> &#42; LV, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/liveintervals">LiveIntervals</a> &#42; LIS) const</>}>
convertToThreeAddress - This method must be implemented by targets that set the M&#95;CONVERTIBLE&#95;TO&#95;3&#95;ADDR flag.

This method must be implemented by targets that set the M&#95;CONVERTIBLE&#95;TO&#95;3&#95;ADDR flag.

When this flag is set, the target may be able to convert a two-address instruction into a true three-address instruction on demand. This allows the <a href="/docs/api/namespaces/llvm/x86">X86</a> target (for example) to convert ADD and SHL instructions into LEA instructions if they would require register copies due to two-addressness.

This method returns a null pointer if the transformation cannot be performed, otherwise it returns the new instruction.

### findCommutedOpIndices() {#a2c3415ef8f310c64d20ff8772825e0b5}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool X86InstrInfo::findCommutedOpIndices (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI, unsigned &amp; SrcOpIdx1, unsigned &amp; SrcOpIdx2) const</>}>
Returns true iff the routine could find two commutable operands in the given machine instruction.

The &#39;SrcOpIdx1&#39; and &#39;SrcOpIdx2&#39; are INPUT and OUTPUT arguments. Their input values can be re-defined in this method only if the input values are not pre-defined, which is designated by the special value &#39;CommuteAnyOperandIndex&#39; assigned to it. If both of indices are pre-defined and refer to some operands, then the method simply returns true if the corresponding operands are commutable and returns false otherwise.

For example, calling this method this way: unsigned Op1 = 1, Op2 = CommuteAnyOperandIndex; findCommutedOpIndices(MI, Op1, Op2); can be interpreted as a query asking to find an operand that would be commutable with the operand#1.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h/#l00344">344</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h">X86InstrInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp/#l02815">2815</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp">X86InstrInfo.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### getFMA3OpcodeToCommuteOperands() {#af39f85bc7795ab54bd45481cb6fbd7ef}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>unsigned X86InstrInfo::getFMA3OpcodeToCommuteOperands (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI, unsigned SrcOpIdx1, unsigned SrcOpIdx2, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/structs/llvm/x86instrfma3group">X86InstrFMA3Group</a> &amp; FMA3Group) const</>}>
Returns an adjusted FMA opcode that must be used in FMA instruction that performs the same computations as the given <code>MI</code> but which has the operands <code>SrcOpIdx1</code> and <code>SrcOpIdx2</code> commuted.

It may return 0 if it is unsafe to commute the operands. Note that a machine instruction (instead of its opcode) is passed as the first parameter to make it possible to analyze the instruction&#39;s uses and commute the first operand of FMA even when it seems unsafe when you look at the opcode. For example, it is Ok to commute the first operand of VFMADD&#42;SD&#95;Int, if ONLY the lowest 64-bit element of the result is used.

The returned FMA opcode may differ from the opcode in the given <code>MI</code>. For example, commuting the operands #1 and #3 in the following FMA FMA213 #1, #2, #3 results into instruction with adjusted opcode: FMA231 #3, #2, #1

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h/#l00367">367</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h">X86InstrInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp/#l02073">2073</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp">X86InstrInfo.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### getGlobalBaseReg() {#a22361ec9d8730e3f4b55ca39260e47f0}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>unsigned X86InstrInfo::getGlobalBaseReg (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machinefunction">MachineFunction</a> &#42; MF) const</>}>
getGlobalBaseReg - Return a virtual register initialized with the the global base register value.

Return a virtual register initialized with the the global base register value.

### getUndefRegClearance() {#ad526a98b9842792511d37f5499693349}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>unsigned X86InstrInfo::getUndefRegClearance (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI, unsigned OpNum, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/targetregisterinfo">TargetRegisterInfo</a> &#42; TRI) const</>}>
Inform the <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/breakfalsedeps">BreakFalseDeps</a> pass how many idle instructions we would like before certain undef register reads.

This catches the VCVTSI2SD family of instructions:

vcvtsi2sdq rax, undef xmm0, xmm14

We should to be careful <em>not</em> to catch VXOR idioms which are presumably handled specially in the pipeline:

vxorps undef xmm1, undef xmm1, xmm1

Like getPartialRegUpdateClearance, this makes a strong assumption that the high bits that are passed-through are not live.

### isCoalescableExtInstr() {#acae9d8928bb20f31f8c38ad023283e44}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool X86InstrInfo::isCoalescableExtInstr (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/register">Register</a> &amp; SrcReg, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/register">Register</a> &amp; DstReg, unsigned &amp; SubIdx) const</>}>
isCoalescableExtInstr - Return true if the instruction is a &quot;coalescable&quot; extension instruction.

That is, it&#39;s like a copy where it&#39;s legal for the source to overlap the destination. e.g. X86::MOVSX64rr32. If this returns true, then it&#39;s expected the pre-extension value is available as a subreg of the result register. This also returns the sub-register index in SubIdx.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h/#l00243">243</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h">X86InstrInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp/#l00123">123</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp">X86InstrInfo.cpp</a>.

### optimizeLoadInstr() {#afbc1088fd64459bec1157940aa59eb69}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>MachineInstr &#42; X86InstrInfo::optimizeLoadInstr (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineregisterinfo">MachineRegisterInfo</a> &#42; MRI, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/register">Register</a> &amp; FoldAsLoadDefReg, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &#42;&amp; DefMI) const</>}>
Try to remove the load by folding it to a register operand at the use.

We fold the load instructions if load defines a virtual register, the virtual register is used once in the same BB, and the instructions in-between do not load or store, and have no side effects.

### shouldScheduleLoadsNear() {#a72ba34ed2a0e75181bfecf7d463156f8}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool X86InstrInfo::shouldScheduleLoadsNear (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sdnode">SDNode</a> &#42; Load1, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/sdnode">SDNode</a> &#42; Load2, int64&#95;t Offset1, int64&#95;t Offset2, unsigned NumLoads) const</>}>
This is a used by the pre-regalloc scheduler to determine (in conjunction with areLoadsFromSameBasePtr) if two loads should be scheduled togther.

On some targets if two loads are loading from addresses in the same cache line, it&#39;s better if they are scheduled together. This function takes two integers that represent the load offsets from the common base address. It returns true if it decides it&#39;s desirable to schedule the two loads together. &quot;NumLoads&quot; is the number of loads that have already been scheduled after Load1.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h/#l00494">494</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h">X86InstrInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp/#l08842">8842</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp">X86InstrInfo.cpp</a>.

### findThreeSrcCommutedOpIndices() {#a4a2c91d247e66309868fb5d2c53a1967}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool X86InstrInfo::findThreeSrcCommutedOpIndices (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI, unsigned &amp; SrcOpIdx1, unsigned &amp; SrcOpIdx2, bool IsIntrinsic=false) const</>}>
Returns true iff the routine could find two commutable operands in the given machine instruction with 3 vector inputs.

The &#39;SrcOpIdx1&#39; and &#39;SrcOpIdx2&#39; are INPUT and OUTPUT arguments. Their input values can be re-defined in this method only if the input values are not pre-defined, which is designated by the special value &#39;CommuteAnyOperandIndex&#39; assigned to it. If both of indices are pre-defined and refer to some operands, then the method simply returns true if the corresponding operands are commutable and returns false otherwise.

For example, calling this method this way: unsigned Op1 = 1, Op2 = CommuteAnyOperandIndex; findThreeSrcCommutedOpIndices(MI, Op1, Op2); can be interpreted as a query asking to find an operand that would be commutable with the operand#1.

If IsIntrinsic is set, operand 1 will be ignored for commuting.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h/#l00702">702</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h">X86InstrInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp/#l02712">2712</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp">X86InstrInfo.cpp</a>.

### foldImmediateImpl() {#a2c1af67dc89f41b440b3b94c521848de}

### isRedundantFlagInstr() {#a3f547705141104f146c9a6fe47508b85}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool X86InstrInfo::isRedundantFlagInstr (<a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; FlagI, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/register">Register</a> SrcReg, <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/register">Register</a> SrcReg2, int64&#95;t ImmMask, int64&#95;t ImmValue, <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/aarch64/aarch64promoteconstant-cpp/#a90f8350fecae261c25be85d38b451bff">const</a> <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; OI, bool &#42; IsSwapped, int64&#95;t &#42; ImmDelta) const</>}>
Returns true when instruction <code>FlagI</code> produces the same flags as <code>OI</code>.

The caller should pass in the results of calling analyzeCompare on <code>OI:</code> <code>SrcReg</code>, <code>SrcReg2</code>, <code>ImmMask</code>, <code>ImmValue</code>. If the flags match <code>OI</code> as if it had the input operands swapped then the function succeeds and sets <code>IsSwapped</code> to true.

Examples of OI, FlagI pairs returning true: CMP %1, 42 and CMP %1, 42 CMP %1, %2 and %3 = SUB %1, %2 TEST %1, %1 and %2 = SUB %1, 0 CMP %1, %2 and %3 = SUB %2, %1 ; IsSwapped=true

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h/#l00718">718</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h">X86InstrInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp/#l04904">4904</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp">X86InstrInfo.cpp</a>.

### isDataInvariant() {#ad4539ba2bb699c968f710984d188246f}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool X86InstrInfo::isDataInvariant (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI)</>}
  labels = {["static"]}>
Returns true if the instruction has no behavior (specified or otherwise) that is based on the value of any of its register operands.

Instructions are considered data invariant even if they set EFLAGS.

A classical example of something that is inherently not data invariant is an indirect jump  the destination is loaded into icache based on the bits set in the jump destination register.

FIXME: This should become part of our instruction tables.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h/#l00256">256</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h">X86InstrInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp/#l00173">173</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp">X86InstrInfo.cpp</a>.
</MemberDefinition>

### isDataInvariantLoad() {#a34662990aab5992b0b1ee00a4dd4ad34}

<MemberDefinition
  prototype={<>bool X86InstrInfo::isDataInvariantLoad (<a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/machineinstr">MachineInstr</a> &amp; MI)</>}
  labels = {["static"]}>
Returns true if the instruction has no behavior (specified or otherwise) that is based on the value loaded from memory or the value of any non-address register operands.

For example, if the latency of the instruction is dependent on the particular bits set in any of the registers <em>or</em> any of the bits loaded from memory.

Instructions are considered data invariant even if they set EFLAGS.

A classical example of something that is inherently not data invariant is an indirect jump  the destination is loaded into icache based on the bits set in the jump destination register.

FIXME: This should become part of our instruction tables.

Declaration at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h/#l00273">273</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-h">X86InstrInfo.h</a>, definition at line <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp/#l00240">240</a> of file <a href="/docs/api/files/lib/lib/target/lib/target/x86/x86instrinfo-cpp">X86InstrInfo.cpp</a>.
